lg.l: "The crops Crops. Kiama, in the colony of New South Wales, had been established by settlers as a centre of wheat farming. are growing nicely,
Much milk is in the dairy,
Much cheese is in the vat;
The flowers lift up their heads.
Has sent us rain and showers;
My crops are saved, thank Heaven,
Thus spoke a farmer one fine morn,
O’erjoyed to see his growing crops,
With reason spoke the farmer thus,

The parching drought Drought. An editorial published in the Kiama Independent on 26 October 1865 described the anxiety caused by the long-continued and disastrous drought which has prevailed so long over the greater part of this territory (p. 2). had dried up
The cattle died in numbers great
From want of the cool stream;
Thus wretchedly all passed their lives,
No welcome cloud o’ercast the sky
Now, will the Governor, thinking well,
“We’ll order, for the good of all,

Humiliation Day.” Humiliation Day. The Governor of New South Wales proclaimed 12 January 1866 as a colony-wide day for general humiliation and rain, to be marked by religious services and the closure of businesses (Kiama Independent, 11 January 1866, p. 2).
The day was kept throughout the land,

The rain came down in showers; Rain came down in showers. Rain was reported to have fallen immediately following the Humiliation Day, followed later that month by copious showers, causing the creeks to run, filling the water-holes, and making our pastures to smile upon us with their beautiful green garments (Kiama Independent, 1 February 1866, p. 3).
